content.description:
A gorge power test piece.  An awkward move right off the deck leads into a balancy ramp that leads to the crux.  Using the drilled pocket (or not), make a long move to some edges and then easier ground.

A nice power route that could be done w/o the drilled pocket, though at a harder grade.
content.location: Shares anchors with the right hand variation of "Pop Goes the Weasle."

content.description: A gorge classic.  Crimpy, techy face climbing leads to a wild roof.  A slightly easier variation branches off to right at the fifth bolt and misses out on the roof.  Do the roof!
content.location: The left most route on the wall.

climbs.name: Moby Dick  (Beach That Whale Direct)
climbs.fa: Dave Lane, Trevor Hobbs, K. Cordner

content.description: Same start as Beach That Whale. Instead of going left around bolt 6 head straight up to the roof. Crux is at the first roof.   There's a 10c pull past the second roof as well.

Start up a powerful layback, turn a weird roof to the left, then finish up the overhanging headwall on even more desperate laybacking and smallish edges.

The rock is better than it looks and largely avoids the flaky garbage to the left of the route line. Could definitely use some traffic though.
content.location: Far right side of the Trestle Wall, where the trail flattens out.  Turns an arête from right-to-left.

content.description: Varied climbing - face to ramp to slab to short corner to more slab.  The first two bolts are very close to each other, it looks like the FA placed one, then changed their mind.  I'd recommend back-cleaning the first if you clip the second, or suffer the rope drag consequences.
content.location: Right next to the river, middle of the wall.

climbs.name: Beach that Whale
climbs.fa: Kelly Cordner, Margy Marshall, Derick Olson, Dave Pedersen

content.description: Flakes to crack to two roofs. Extend bolt with full sling below 2nd roof or back clean to reduce drag.  Cruxes at bolts 10 and 12.  Unusual technique gets you past 1st roof crux. Beach that whale!
content.protection: 13 bolts.  You probably need a 70m rope for this route.
content.location: right of 12c and Barbella's new 10a.  Look for 2 obvious large roofs.  belay is on trail near stream.

content.description: Classic Owen's pumpy edge pulling. Start out by bearhugging small flakes and edges.  The crux comes at the 4th bolt and is a balancy yet powerful move leading to a good horizontal.  At this point the route used to go straight up but a key hold has broken. You can still go straight up but most people move right, do a long reach and come back left to the jugs.  After a good shake on a huge sidepull, pull edges to the top. Pumpy, long and fun.

Easy climbing on crumbly rock leads to a bouldery roof section (I imagine going right at the roof and climbing around it would be "off-route") and then an slightly overhanging headwall. The headwall has fixed draws as of 01/2021. The rock isn't of the best quality but it should clean up with traffic; too bad the reinforcement job on some holds was done clumsily. Nice movements.
content.location: The route to the right of Bazooka Country.
